His Highness the Shaikh of Bahrein arrived at Aden in S.S. STRATHAIRD at 1200 Wednesday 19th January. He was received by representatives of the Acting Governor and Commander in Chief and Commander M. Henstock, Royal Navy, Naval Officer-in-Charge, Aden, in the absence on the sick list of His Excellency. Accompanied by the Naval- Officer-in-Charge, His Highness embarked in H.M.S. LONDONDERRY being received by a Petty Officers Guard. As soon as all stores had been purchased, LONDONDERRY sailed for Jedda at 1630. 9. Fine weather with light to moderate winds was experienced during the passage. His Highness was most considerate and grateful for anything which was done for the comfort of himself and his party, ielegrams to various personages were sent by him but it was impracticable to get in touch with S.S. ISLAMI in which ship it is understood the ladies of the party were travelling, until after our arrival at Jedda. A flag of Bahrein had not been included in the luggage of the party but a flag, which was approved by His Highness, was made onboard using a red flag with strips of white bunting. The flag was required for saluting on arrival at Jedda. H./11. It was therefore decided not to approach the coast until the position of the ship was accurately determined ? with a consequent delay of approximately two hours in the programmejC 13. Both His Royal Highness The Viceroy of the Hedjaz and His Highness the Shaikh of Bahrein left the ship together being saluted by an officers guard and salutes of 21 guns and 11 guns respectively. British Legation, Jedda, February 22nd., 1938. Sir, It was believed, at the time when my despatch No. 24 of February 3rd. was written, that His Highness the Shaikh of Bahrain would return to the Persian Gulf fcy land. Indeed, he had accepted the offer of Ibn Saud to send him by that route. In the end, however, he decided to go to Karachi by sea from Jedda. The reason which he gave me was that to transport so large a party across Arabia would have thrown an intolerable burden upon the transport of his generous host, and indeed, the conveyance of about twenty visitors with some seventy followers to Ujair by land v/ould have required a large number of motor vehicles, and at the height of the pilgrim season. 2. It would have been more convenient if the Saudi authorities had made up their mrnds about the change of plan a little earlier, but in the end all went well. With the help of the Jedda agents of the Turner Morrison Line it was arranged that the s.s. ’'Islami”, the largest and best of the Indian pilgrim ships, should sail first after the Haj.j and should take His Highness and his party, as well as the eleven motor cars which His Highness had received as presents in the course of/ The Right Honourable Anthony Eden, M.C., M.P., ‘k 0 *’ &c., &c.of his visit. Another present consisted of 40 rifles and 4,000 rounds of ammunition. To ensure that there should he no difficulty about these weapons I telegraphed to the authorities at Karachi as well as to the Political Agent at Bahrain. 3. His Highness came down from Mecca on February 16th. and left the following day. Everything had already been done about the loading of the cars etc., and there remained nothing to do but to supply a considerable number of Emergency Passes for members of the suite who had lost their papers and to furnish at the last moment a certificate for several men who had not been counted before. I went on board the 'Islami' at the last moment and found the Shaikh comfortable and content. He had I think enjoyed his stay till the last, though he seemed a little tired. 4. The Amir Saud, who came to Jedda with the Shaikh, spoke of him to me with high appreciation. As a rule, he said, the Persian Gulf amirs were rather Boeotian; but not so the Shaikh of Bahrain. His remark may be compared with the statement which he is alleged to have made to the Shaikh when he was in Bahrain. (Bushire despatch No. 13 -S d ated January 3rd., 1938), that the ruling family of Qatar are merely ,, animals ,, . 5. CONFIDENTIAL. [E 977/30/91] Si?' R. Bullard to Mr. Eden.—(Received February 21.) (No. 24.) Sir, Jedda, February 3, 1938. I HAVE the honour to report on the visit of His Highness the Sheikh of Bahrein, to which your telegram No. 2 of the 6th January refers. 2. Shortly beforehand Ibn Saud mentioned the visit to me with obvious pleasure. He said what a good man the sheikh was, and reminded me that he and the sheikh were both of Anayza tribal origin. 3. Fuad Bey informed me that the King had been deeply touched by the honours and attentions paid to the Amir Saud when he visited Bahrein last December, and was resolved to repay the debt of hospitality and courtesy with interest. He asked whether it was a fact that we now gave the sheikh the title of £t Highness,” and, learning that this was so, he said that the Saudi Government would use that form of address. He said that it was proposed to give the sheikh a salute of twenty-one guns when he landed, and asked to how many he was entitled according to our reckoning. He made no comment when I informed him, after enquiry from Bahrein, that His Majesty’s Government had accorded to His Highness a salute of eleven guns, and I forebore to comment on the proposal to give the sheikh a larger number here, feeling that that was, after all, Ibn Sand’s concern. I believe that the salute fired did, in fact, consist of twenty-one guns, but it was inaudible at the quay where the sheikh landed, and was, moreover, complicated by explosions from a quarry, where a workman thought it would be amusing to let off twenty-one of a large number of charges which happened to be laid. 4. The reception provided by the Saudi authorities was very handsome. The full Saudi air fleet of six machines went out to meet the Londonderry and circled slowly round several times. Shortly after I had gone on board the Amir Feisal arrived, to be greeted with twenty-one guns from the ship. The meeting between the Amir and the sheikh was very friendly, and the sheikh was pleased with the programme of the ceremonial to be observed, which was read out to him by a Saudi official. On the ship the Amir insisted on the guest’s going in front of him. To maintain his dignity he whispered to me that this was out of respect for the sheikh’s age, but I have no doubt that it was by order of the King. In any case, the sheikh was quite equal to the occasion and accepted this not unreasonable act of courtesy with no more than the conventional resistance. 5. The sheikh seemed to have been very comfortable and happy on the Londonderry, and was most grateful for the attention shown to him by Captain Dowding. He left the ship full of thanks. 6. By the desire of the King, the Amir and the sheikh left in the same launch. A salute of twenty-one guns was fired for the Amir by the Londonderi'y, and after a short interval a salute of eleven guns for the sheikh. 7. The sheikh was met on the quay by the Amir Saud, who had come to Jedda for the purpose, and by a guard of honour and a great concourse of official and unofficial notables. There was a short reception in the new quarantine building, at which I had a place of honour on the right of the Amir Baud, who had the sheikh on his left. The sheikh then left for the Jedda office of the Minister of Finance, which had been prepared for his reception. He lunched with the Amir Feisal, as Viceroy, in the Khuzam Palace outside Jedda, and, after returning to his quarters in Jedda, set off to Mecca at about 4 p.m. I called on him before he left. He had not yet assumed the pilgrim garb, though ordinarily a pilgrim who intended to go to Mecca first, not to Medina, would land in the “ ihram,” but he put it on for the journey to Mecca. How this derogation from the religious rule was managed I do not know. 8. According to the press there was an official reception in Mecca the next morning, including a parade of troops, police, school-children, &c., and an address [230 x—4] February 21, 1938 Section 4. Copy No. V ~ '•* ’ * 'by the Mayor of Mecca; and on three successive days the sheikh was entertained to dinner hy the King, the Amir Saud and the Amir Feisal. 9. The sheikh had accepted the proposal of Ihn Saud that he should return home by land via Riyadh after the pilgrimage. This meant that any entertain ment given in his honour by His Majesty’s Legation must be before the pilgrimage. It was ascertained that His Highness intended to come to Jedda on the 28th January to meet certain members of his family who were arriving by an Indian pilgrim ship, with whom he would proceed straight to Medina, and he kindly accepted an invitation to attend a reception at the Legation on that day. In the end it was arranged that his family should be taken to him at Mecca and that they should travel to Medina by the Ashaira Road instead of by the ordinary route via Jedda, but His Highness made a special journey to Jedda to be present at the reception, which was attended by the leading members of the British community and the most important official and unofficial Saudis. The sheikh was the life and soul of the party, talking with equal enthusiasm about the kindness and hospitality shown to him by Ibn Saud and by Captain Dowding, and the restoration of order in Arabia by the King and the wonders of H.M.S. Nelson and the Queen Mary. 10. It is pleasant to see the friendly relations between Saudi Arabia and Bahrein, as compared with the friction to which an end was put only two years ago by the agreements about customs dues and other points then in dispute, and if Ibn Saud uses thd occasion to make a small demonstration of pan-Arabism no serious harm will be done. The feeling found expression in a leading article in the Umm-al-Qura of the 28th January. It is headed “His Majesty the King gives an admirable example of Moslem friendship and Arab brotherhood ”—a phrase which occurs several times in the article itself. The article is not worth translating. It speaks of the welcome afforded to the Amir Saud in Bahrein as a demonstration of brotherly unity, and then comes a paragraph which may be given in full as a specimen of the whole :— “We are sure that the Arab nation whose union has been effected by His Majesty King Abdul Aziz will take a step (please God !) towards the establishment of its great unification based on understanding and sincerity between its kings, amirs, peoples and individuals. Such admirable Islamic manifestations are the distinguished foundations on which the lofty buildings of union and unity will be firmly based.” 11. titleInfo.title: Coll 30/153 'Visit of Sheikh of Bahrain to Mecca.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the rear to the front of the file.

Foliation: the foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1, and terminates at the inside back cover with 47; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.

mods.abstract: The file concerns the visit of the Ruler of Bahrain, Shaikh Sir Hamad bin Isa al Khalifah [Ḥamad bin ‘Īsá Āl Khalīfah], to Mecca in order to undertake the Hajj (January 1938).The papers include: the decision to allow Shaikh Hamad to travel to Saudi Arabia aboard a Royal Navy ship (HMS Londonderry); reports on the Shaikh's visit by HM Minister at Jedda (Sir Reader William Bullard); and a report on the Shaikh's passage on the Londonderry, with papers concerning a request for payment for the purchase of articles on board ship for the use of the Shaikh, June - July 1938.The file includes a divider, which gives a list of correspondence references contained in the file by year. This is placed at the back of the correspondence.
